tn.ref: we are your flesh and bone
tn.text: This phrase means "a relative." AT: "we are related to you" or "we are of the same family" - (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This is historical information. Saul had been their king before David. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: You will shepherd my people Israel, and you will become ruler over Israel
tn.text: These two clauses mean basically the same thing and emphasize that Yahweh had chosen David to be king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: You will shepherd my people Israel
tn.text: Here ruling over the people is spoken of as shepherding them. AT: "You will care for my people Israel" or "You will rule over my people Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: They anointed David king over Israel
tn.text: To "anoint" is a symbolic act to show that they recognized that God had chosen David as king. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
David and the army of Israel attack Jerusalem.

tn.ref: You will not come here except to be turned away by the blind and the lame
tn.text: This can be stated in a positive form. AT: "If you come here, even the blind and the lame will be able to turn you away"
Here "the blind" and "the lame" are nominal adjectives. AT: "those people who cannot see and those who cannot walk" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])

tn.ref: David said, "Those who attack the Jebusites
tn.text: David was speaking to his soldiers. AT: "David said to his soldiers, "Those who want to get rid of the Jebus people" (UDB)

Possible meanings are 1) this refers to people who are truly lame and blind or 2) this is a metonym that speaks about the Jebusites inside the city of Jerusalem as if they were all weak and handicapped. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
those who work with wood
those who work with stone or brick

tn.ref: Shammua ... Shobab ... Nathan ... Solomon ... Ibhar ... Elishua ... Nepheg ... Japhia ... Elishama ... Eliada ... Eliphelet
tn.text: These are the names of David's sons. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: more sons and daughters were born to him
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "he had more sons and daughters" or "they bore him more sons and daughters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "that his wives bore for him" or "he had" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: David had been anointed as king over Israel
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Israel had anointed David as king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: they all went out looking for him
tn.text: This phrase refers to some Philistines looking for David. It uses exaggeration to show how much the Philistines wanted to find David. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]] )
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Yahweh has burst through my enemies before me like a bursting flood of water
tn.text: Here David speaks of the victory that Yahweh brought as if it were a flood of water that overflowed its banks and covered the land, causing destruction. AT: "Yahweh has overwhelmed my enemies like a flood overwhelms the land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
They "came up" because the Philistines lived at a lower elevation than David's stronghold.
This is the name of a place. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"Balsam" is a type of tree, and the "woods" describe many balsam trees growing together. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: When you hear ... Yahweh will have gone out before you to attack the army of the Philistines
tn.text: This is the continuation of Yahweh's instruction to David that began in [[:en:bible:notes:2sa:05:22|5:23]]. Yahweh here speaks of himself in the third person. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])

tn.ref: When you hear the sound of marching in the wind blowing through the balsam treetops
tn.text: This speaks of the sound of the leaves rustling as wind blows through them as if it were the sound of marching. AT: "When the wind blowing through the tops of the balsam trees sounds like men marching" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These are the names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
